author: Charie Abarca
title: PH seafarers told to avoid Red Sea deployment
text:
MANILA, Philippines — Amid the escalation of conflict in the Red Sea, the Philippine government advised Filipino seafarers to exercise their “right-to-refuse-sailing” in the area or to avoid it altogether.
The reminder was aired through the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) in an advisory issued early Friday morning.
“The DFA advises the public that the danger to all shipping in the Red Sea remains. This situation has worsened due in part to the conflict escalation in the Red Sea that poses a clear and present danger to all Filipino seafarers working in the area,” the advisory reads.
ADVERTISEMENT “The DFA therefore urges Filipino seafarers to exercise prudent choice and their right-to-refuse sailing in the Red Sea. Philippine nationals should avoid the area altogether unless absolutely necessary for their livelihood,” it adds.
FEATURED STORIES GLOBALNATION Alice Guo seen in Kuala Lumpur based on photo received by PAOCC GLOBALNATION Alice Guo’s passport reported to Interpol – Hontiveros GLOBALNATION Sheila Guo, Cassandra Ong back in PH after arrest in Indonesia The advisory was issued after Houthi rebels off the Yemeni port of Hodeidah attacked Greek-owned oil Tanker MT Sounion.
The Department of Migrant Workers (DMW) said all 23 Filipino crew members on board have been successfully rescued from the ship and are now on their way to a safe port.
Immediate repatriation of the 23 Filipino seafarers will be arranged by the DFA, DMW, and the Overseas Workers Welfare Administration.
Upon arrival in the country, the seafarers will be provided with psycho-social, financial, training and reintegration support for their families.
Prior to the attack, the Philippine government already barred Filipino seafarers from boarding vessels passing through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden.
DMW required manning agencies to submit a written guarantee that passenger or cruise vessels with Filipino crew members will not traverse the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden, which have been designated as “war-like zones.”
ADVERTISEMENT Aside from the “affirmation letter,” the DMW also required manning agencies to submit their vessels’ detailed itinerary during the processing of crew employment contracts or before deployment.
